title: Introduction to Physics - Forces and Motion

data.title: Today's Learning Goals
objectives: Understand Newton's Three Laws of Motion
Learn about different types of forces in nature
Apply physics concepts to real-world examples

data.title: What is Physics?
data.topic: Physics is the science that studies matter, energy, and their interactions. It helps us understand how the universe works, from the smallest particles to the largest galaxies.

keywords.description: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion, unless acted upon by an external force.
The acceleration of an object is directly proportional to the net force acting on it. F = ma
For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

data.title: Types of Forces
data.content1: The force that attracts objects with mass toward each other. On Earth, gravity pulls everything toward the center with an acceleration of 9.8 m/sÂ².
data.content2: The force that opposes motion between surfaces in contact. It can be static (preventing motion) or kinetic (opposing ongoing motion).

data.title: Real-World Applications
details: Car Safety: Seatbelts and airbags use Newton's First Law to protect passengers during sudden stops
Sports: Athletes use physics principles to improve performance - projectile motion in basketball, friction in running
Technology: Smartphones, computers, and GPS systems all rely on physics principles like electromagnetism and relativity

data.title: Motion Concepts
data.content1: Speed is how fast something moves (scalar). Velocity includes both speed and direction (vector). A car going 60 mph north has a different velocity than one going 60 mph south.
data.content2: The rate of change of velocity. When you press the gas pedal, you accelerate. When you brake, you decelerate (negative acceleration).

data.title: Problem-Solving Strategy
details: Identify what you know and what you need to find
Choose the appropriate physics equation or principle
Substitute known values and solve for the unknown
Check if your answer makes sense in the real world

data.title: Review of Today's Learning
summarys: Newton's Three Laws of Motion govern how objects move and interact with forces in our universe
Different types of forces (gravity, friction, electromagnetic) affect motion in various ways, and understanding these helps us explain everyday phenomena
